an4.40:1.1.pli: Atha kho udāyī brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho udāyī brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.40:1.1.eng: Then Udāyī the brahmin went up to the Buddha, … and asked him,

an4.40:1.3.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ yaññaṃ vaṇṇemi;

an4.40:1.4.pli: na panāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ yaññaṃ na vaṇṇemi.
an4.40:1.4.eng: Nor do I criticize all sacrifices. …

an4.40:1.5.pli: Yathārūpe kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññe gāvo haññanti, ajeḷakā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti;
an4.40:1.5.eng: Take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of animals are slaughtered.

an4.40:1.6.pli: evarūpaṃ kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sārambhaṃ yaññaṃ na vaṇṇemi.
an4.40:1.6.eng: I don’t praise that kind of violent sacrifice.

an4.40:1.8.pli: Evarūpañhi, brāhmaṇa, sārambhaṃ yaññaṃ na upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā.

an4.40:2.1.pli: Yathārūpe ca kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṃ āpajjanti;
an4.40:2.1.eng: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of animals are not slaughtered.

an4.40:2.2.pli: evarūpaṃ kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, nirārambhaṃ yaññaṃ vaṇṇemi, yadidaṃ niccadānaṃ anukulayaññaṃ.
an4.40:2.2.eng: I do praise that kind of non-violent sacrifice; for example, a regular gift as an propitious sacrifice.

an4.40:2.4.pli: Evarūpañhi, brāhmaṇa, nirārambhaṃ yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannāti.

an4.40:3.1.eng: The kind of sacrifice that’s allowable and timely,

an4.40:4.1.eng: The Buddhas—<j>who have drawn back the veil from the world,

an4.40:4.4.eng: as they are expert in sacrifice.

an4.40:5.1.eng: When you’ve prepared a suitable offering,

an4.40:5.2.eng: whether as sacrifice or for ancestors,

an4.40:5.4.eng: in the fertile field of spiritual practitioners.

an4.40:6.2.eng: to those worthy of a religious donation,

an4.40:6.4.eng: and even the deities are pleased.

an4.40:7.2.eng: sacrifices like this, with a mind of letting go,

an4.41:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of developing immersion further.

an4.41:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati;
an4.41:1.3.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life.

an4.41:1.4.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanappaṭilābhāya saṃvattati;
an4.41:1.4.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.

an4.41:1.5.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati;
an4.41:1.5.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.

an4.41:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
an4.41:1.6.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.

an4.41:2.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati?
an4.41:2.1.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life?

an4.41:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.41:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an4.41:2.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati.
an4.41:2.3.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life.

an4.41:3.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanappaṭilābhāya saṃvattati?
an4.41:3.1.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision?

an4.41:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ālokasaññaṃ manasi karoti, divāsaññaṃ adhiṭṭhāti—
an4.41:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant applies their mind to the perception of light, focusing on the perception of day:

an4.41:3.3.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
an4.41:3.3.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

an4.41:3.4.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
an4.41:3.4.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

an4.41:3.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanappaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
an4.41:3.5.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.

an4.41:4.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati?
an4.41:4.1.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness?

an4.41:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;
an4.41:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

an4.41:4.3.pli: viditā saññā …pe… viditā vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
an4.41:4.3.eng: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away. They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

an4.41:4.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati.
an4.41:4.4.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.

an4.41:5.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati?
an4.41:5.1.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements?

an4.41:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati:
an4.41:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

an4.41:5.3.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
an4.41:5.3.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

an4.41:5.4.pli: iti vedanā, iti vedanāya samudayo, iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
an4.41:5.4.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

an4.41:5.5.pli: iti saññā, iti saññāya samudayo, iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
an4.41:5.5.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

an4.41:5.6.pli: iti saṅkhārā, iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo, iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo;
an4.41:5.6.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.

an4.41:5.7.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
an4.41:5.7.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

an4.41:5.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
an4.41:5.8.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.

an4.41:5.9.eng: These are the four ways of developing immersion further.

an4.41:5.10.pli: Idañca pana metaṃ, bhikkhave, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ pārāyane puṇṇakapañhe:
an4.41:5.10.eng: And it was in this connection that I said in ‘The Way to the Far Shore’, in ‘The Questions of Puṇṇaka’:

an4.41:6.1.eng: ‘Having appraised the world high and low,

an4.41:6.2.eng: there is nothing in the world that disturbs them.

an4.41:6.3.eng: Peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope,

an4.41:6.4.eng: they’ve crossed over rebirth and old age, I declare.’”

an4.42:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of answering questions.

an4.42:1.3.eng: There is a question that should be answered categorically.

an4.42:1.4.eng: There is a question that should be answered analytically.

an4.42:1.5.eng: There is a question that should be answered with a counter-question.

an4.42:1.6.eng: There is a question that should be set aside.

an4.42:1.7.eng: These are the four ways of answering questions.

an4.42:2.4.eng: while a fourth is set aside.

an4.42:3.1.eng: That sort of mendicant, <j>who knows each of these,

an4.42:3.4.eng: in the four kinds of questions.

an4.42:4.4.eng: what the meaning is and what it isn’t.

an4.42:5.1.eng: Shunning what is not the meaning,

an4.42:5.2.eng: an astute person grasps the meaning.

an4.42:5.3.eng: An attentive one, comprehending the meaning,

an4.43:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.43:1.3.pli: Kodhagaru na saddhammagaru, makkhagaru na saddhammagaru, lābhagaru na saddhammagaru, sakkāragaru na saddhammagaru.
an4.43:1.3.eng: People who value anger, or denigration, or material things, or honor rather than the true teaching.

an4.43:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.43:1.4.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.

an4.43:2.1.pli: Cattārome, bhikkhave, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.43:2.1.eng: These four individuals are found in the world.

an4.43:2.3.pli: Saddhammagaru na kodhagaru, saddhammagaru na makkhagaru, saddhammagaru na lābhagaru, saddhammagaru na sakkāragaru.
an4.43:2.3.eng: People who value the true teaching rather than anger, or denigration, or material things, or honor.

an4.43:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an4.43:2.4.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.

an4.43:3.1.eng: Mendicants who value anger and denigration,

an4.43:3.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.

an4.43:4.1.eng: But those who value the true teaching,

an4.43:4.2.eng: who have lived it, and are living it now,

an4.43:4.3.eng: these do grow in the teaching

an4.43:4.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.”

an4.44:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things oppose the true teaching.

an4.44:1.3.pli: Kodhagarutā na saddhammagarutā, makkhagarutā na saddhammagarutā, lābhagarutā na saddhammagarutā, sakkāragarutā na saddhammagarutā.
an4.44:1.3.eng: Valuing anger, denigration, material things, and honor rather than the true teaching.

an4.44:1.4.eng: These are the four things that oppose the true teaching.

an4.44:2.1.eng: These four things are the true teaching.

an4.44:2.3.pli: Saddhammagarutā na kodhagarutā, saddhammagarutā na makkhagarutā, saddhammagarutā na lābhagarutā, saddhammagarutā na sakkāragarutā.
an4.44:2.3.eng: Valuing the true teaching rather than anger, denigration, material things, and honor.

an4.44:2.4.eng: These are the four things that are the true teaching.

an4.44:3.1.eng: A mendicant who values anger and denigration,

an4.44:3.3.eng: doesn’t grow in the true teaching,

an4.44:3.4.eng: like a rotten seed in a good field.

an4.44:4.1.eng: But those who value the true teaching,

an4.44:4.2.eng: who have lived it, and are living it now,

an4.44:4.3.eng: these do grow in the teaching,

an4.45:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an4.45:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an4.45:1.2.pli: Atha kho rohitasso devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rohitasso devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.45:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Rohitassa, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

an4.45:2.1.pli: “Yattha nu kho, bhante, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, sakkā nu kho so, bhante, gamanena lokassa anto ñātuṃ vā daṭṭhuṃ vā pāpuṇituṃ vā”ti?
an4.45:2.1.eng: “Sir, is it possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn?”

an4.45:2.2.pli: “Yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī”ti.
an4.45:2.2.eng: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.”

an4.45:3.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

an4.45:3.3.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’”ti.

an4.45:4.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, rohitasso nāma isi ahosiṃ bhojaputto iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo.
an4.45:4.1.eng: Once upon a time, I was a seer called Rohitassa, son of the benefactors. I was a sky-walker with psychic powers.

an4.45:4.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo javo ahosi, seyyathāpi nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasirena tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya.
an4.45:4.2.eng: I was as fast as a light arrow easily shot across the shadow of a palm tree by a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow.

an4.45:4.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo padavītihāro ahosi, seyyathāpi nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimo samuddo.
an4.45:4.3.eng: My stride was such that it could span from the eastern ocean to the western ocean.

an4.45:4.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpena javena samannāgatassa evarūpena ca padavītihārena evarūpaṃ icchāgataṃ uppajji:
an4.45:4.4.eng: Having such speed and stride, this wish came to me:

an4.45:4.5.eng: ‘I will reach the end of the world by traveling.’

an4.45:4.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṃ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṃ antarāyeva kālaṅkato.
an4.45:4.6.eng: I traveled for my whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—and I passed away along the way, never reaching the end of the world.

an4.45:5.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.”

an4.45:5.3.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’”ti.

an4.45:6.1.pli: “‘Yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyan’ti vadāmi.
an4.45:6.1.eng: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.

an4.45:6.2.pli: Na cāhaṃ, āvuso, appatvāva lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmi.
an4.45:6.2.eng: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.

an4.45:6.3.pli: Api cāhaṃ, āvuso, imasmiṃyeva byāmamatte kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca paññāpemi lokasamudayañca lokanirodhañca lokanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadanti.
an4.45:6.3.eng: For it is in this fathom-long carcass with its perception and mind that I describe the world, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

an4.45:7.1.eng: The end of the world can never

an4.45:7.3.eng: But without reaching the end of the world,

an4.45:8.1.eng: So an intelligent person, understanding the world,

an4.45:8.2.eng: has completed the spiritual journey, <j>and gone to the end of the world.

an4.45:8.3.eng: Assuaged, knowing the end of the world,

an4.45:8.4.eng: they do not hope for this world or the next.”

an4.46:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
an4.46:1.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an4.46:1.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ rohitasso devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhikkhave, rohitasso devaputto maṃ etadavoca:
an4.46:1.2.eng: “Tonight, the glorious godling Rohitassa, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me:

an4.46:1.3.pli: ‘yattha nu kho, bhante, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, sakkā nu kho so, bhante, gamanena lokassa anto ñātuṃ vā daṭṭhuṃ vā pāpuṇituṃ vā’ti?
an4.46:1.3.eng: ‘Sir, is it possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn?’ …

an4.46:1.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, rohitassaṃ devaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
an4.46:1.4.eng: (The rest is the same as the previous discourse, AN 4.45.)

an4.46:1.5.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’ti.

an4.46:1.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, rohitasso devaputto maṃ etadavoca:

an4.46:1.9.pli: yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmi’.

an4.46:2.1.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, rohitasso nāma isi ahosiṃ bhojaputto iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo.

an4.46:2.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo javo ahosi, seyyathāpi nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasirena tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya.

an4.46:2.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo padavītihāro ahosi, seyyathāpi nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimo samuddo.

an4.46:2.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpena javena samannāgatassa evarūpena ca padavītihārena evarūpaṃ icchāgataṃ uppajji:

an4.46:2.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṃ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṃ antarāyeva kālaṅkato.

an4.46:3.3.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’ti.

an4.46:3.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, rohitassaṃ devaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:

an4.46:4.1.pli: ‘Yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ, taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’ti.

an4.46:4.2.pli: Na cāhaṃ, āvuso, appatvāva lokassa antaṃ dukkhassantakiriyaṃ vadāmi.

an4.46:4.3.pli: Api cāhaṃ, āvuso, imasmiṃyeva byāmamatte kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca paññāpemi lokasamudayañca lokanirodhañca lokanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadanti.

an4.47:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are very far apart.

an4.47:1.5.eng: The near and the far shore of the ocean. …

an4.47:1.7.pli: Yato ca, bhikkhave, verocano abbhudeti yattha ca atthameti;
an4.47:1.7.eng: Where the sun rises and where it sets. …

an4.47:1.9.eng: The teaching of the virtuous and the teaching of the wicked. …

an4.47:1.11.eng: These are the four things very far apart.

an4.47:2.1.eng: The firmament is far from the earth;

an4.47:2.2.eng: they say the other shore of the ocean is far;

an4.47:2.3.eng: and where the sun rises is far

an4.47:2.5.eng: But even further apart than that, they say,

an4.47:2.6.eng: is the teaching of the virtuous from the wicked.

an4.47:3.1.eng: The company of the virtuous is reliable;

an4.47:3.2.eng: as long as it remains, it stays the same.

an4.47:3.3.eng: But the company of the wicked is fickle,

an4.47:3.4.eng: and so the teaching of the virtuous <j>is far from the wicked.”

an4.48:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an4.48:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an4.48:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā visākho pañcālaputto upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti, poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā pariyāpannāya anissitāya.
an4.48:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son, was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.

an4.48:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an4.48:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall. He sat down on the seat spread out,

an4.48:2.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhikkhave, upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā pariyāpannāya anissitāyā”ti?
an4.48:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, who was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk?”

an4.48:2.2.pli: “Āyasmā, bhante, visākho pañcālaputto upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā pariyāpannāya anissitāyā”ti.
an4.48:2.2.eng: “Sir, it was Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son.”

an4.48:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ visākhaṃ pañcālaputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.48:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Visākha,

an4.48:3.3.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, visākha, bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā pariyāpannāya anissitāyāti.
an4.48:3.3.eng: It’s good that you educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk, with words that are polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.

an4.48:4.1.eng: Though an astute person is mixed up with fools,

an4.48:4.2.eng: they don’t know unless he speaks.

an4.48:4.3.eng: But when he speaks they know,

an4.48:4.4.eng: he’s teaching the state free of death.

an4.48:5.1.eng: He should speak and illustrate the teaching,

an4.48:5.2.eng: holding up the banner of the seers.

an4.48:5.3.eng: Words well spoken are the seers’ banner,

an4.48:5.4.eng: for the teaching is the banner of the seers.”
